bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Albert E. Truby, March 8, 1941

div1.p: [Hench] thanks Truby for his letter of support to the Cuban government. He finds fault with Truby's description of the location of the yellow fever ward as northwest of the hospital grounds.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Albert E. Truby, March 8, 1941
div1.opener:
Handwritten letter to Gen Truby
3/8/41
My dear Gen Truby
div1.p:
I am most grateful to you for sending me such a fine letter
to take to Dr Ramos I am sure that, in conjunction with
one I just received from Gen Kean, it will help me greatly
in Havana. With the weight of your authority behind me I
believe, or at least hope that the Cubans will graciously
accept my evidence & that we can get together to memoralize
the sites accurately, for the greater glory of all concerned,
assuredly including Finlay.

I enclose a carbon copy of Gen. Kean's letter, also
received this morning. It was written in long hand.
You will note that he says “I am also familiar with the
location southwest of the Military Hospital where was
located”.... etc. I am taking the [unclear] of calling your
attention to his statement southwest”. In your letter you
state in the 4th paragraph “... our yellow fever wards
near the north western border of the hospital grounds.”

I am so anxious to avoid growing Ramos, Lage et
al any opportunity for picking flaws in our argument
& wondered if you were willing to change your letter a
bit on that direction. I realize that there is some doubt
in your mind as to whether the memorial fence, sign & tree
(false site) are exactly where the yellow fever wards were
or whether the latter were somewhat nearer the ocean
(more north west) from the fence & sign. But if you consult
that enclosed little note & also (if you still have it) the 1902
U S Army map of camp Columbia. I think we must
say that the yellow fever wards were more accurately
southwest or certainly west of the Post hospital rather
than northwest. I hate to bother you over such a small
point but as I haven't yet received my reports back
from Moran and Mrs Agramonte from Havana I think I
have time to send your letter back for your correction on that
point. To save you from copying the letter all over
I am returning the original (keeping the carbons) & you
could just change that one word [unclear] to southwest
or to were as your conscience dictates.

By the way you recall we had a little discussion
also which direction was moved in relation to the
office's quarters (bachelor) Even before I had these 1902 &
1907 U S Army map I submitted your drawing of its camp
grounds (a photostat of it) to Gen Kean without mentioning
the directions to him. He wrote that he thought your map
was essentially correct except that the direction sign
wasn't quite right. I can see how one would naturally
consider the oceon & La Playa “north” of the
hospital when in reality it was northwest.

Again let me say how much I appreciate your
wonderful help & [unclear] your [unclear]
